p: Erythritol is a small polyol (four-carbon, tetritol) naturally found in fruit and vegetables, mushrooms, and fermented foods like wine and soy sauce. Its sweetness is 60â€“80% that of sucrose [ 78]. Being a small molecule, approximately 90% of the erythritol assumed with food is readily absorbed, by diffusion, by the small intestine, while approximately 10% reaches the large intestine. Absorbed erythritol is minimally metabolized by the tissues, and it is essentially excreted unused in the urine [ 80, 81, 82]. Therefore, erythritol contributes no calories and does not affect blood glucose levels [ 83]. Moreover, as erythritol is almost totally absorbed, it causes fewer intestinal symptoms [ 78, 84].
